channel.title: Best language to code
channel.description:
what would be the best language to learn to code server hosting protection scripts, e.g, anti-ddos, null routes, botnets, etc,.
I was think C# or C++ but since I don't know much about either, I'm asking you what would be the best language?
NOTE: Not for moparscape but for web hosting...

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

Python Python Python Python Python

Read full topic

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:40, topic:268386”][quote author=yakman link=topic=354206.msg2730911#msg2730911 date=1238708139]
Cheese Police, could you please elaborate on these hardware firewalls and switches.

am i right in thinking they are like flood control on an irc client, where if x amount of packets arrive in a time, then block…

i suppose since they are hardware firewalls, they use less processing power to block packets.
[/quote]

well, not necessarily less processing power, they are dedicated filtering machines. i should have worded what i said a bit differently, switches are hardware anyway, so the statement was a bit redundant. regardless, switches are basically big beefy routers that are designed to plow through a bunch of traffic.

going back to the hardware firewalls, yeah, it is basically throttling/flood control, with a few extra rules thrown in.[/quote]
Cheese Police is correct, the hardware firewalls monitor packets sent/recieved and throttle the amount of bandwidth used. If the attack is massive, the firewall may null route connecting addresses for a short period of time to minimize traffic flow. I’ve seen some of these beauties, however I don’t own one due to their high cost.

Read full topic

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @SpamRex SpamRex
item.description:
@SpamRex wrote:

[quote=“zstars, post:23, topic:268386”]Nowadays my favourite languages are C++, C#, Python and Lua

(Disclaimer: This is a personal opinion and I do not make any warranty, expressed or implied, for the accuracy, completeness, or usefulness of this information)

  • C++ (Not to confuse with C): Very powerful languge, high execution and memory efficiency, but low compilation speed and steep learning curve.

  • C#: Modern language, probably best IDE ever, RAD, good GUIs in a short dev time. Similar to Java, with a different philosophy and a more powerful core language. Not so good for web applets.

  • Python: Dynamic scripting / programming language, fast theorethical dev times but very bad IDEs. Not bad for embedding.

  • Lua: Not good as a stand-alone language, but very good for embedding.[/quote]
    gtfo

Read full topic

i suppose since they are hardware firewalls, they use less processing power to block packets.[/quote]

well, not necessarily less processing power, they are dedicated filtering machines. i should have worded what i said a bit differently, switches are hardware anyway, so the statement was a bit redundant. regardless, switches are basically big beefy routers that are designed to plow through a bunch of traffic.

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @Wrauld Wrauld
item.description:
@Wrauld wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:37, topic:268386”]most often efforts of countering ddos are useless at server level if the attack is big enough; small attacks should be easy to counter, but probably not worth the trouble considering most of the time the people behind the attack are retarded/have limited resources.

the best, and probably only plausible defense is at the data center. data centers such as steadfast in chicago have very high bandwidth lines and many, many hardware firewalls, switches, etc, in order to render high volume attacks useless. nothing is truly safe though.[/quote]
Thank you.

Read full topic

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @Wrauld Wrauld
item.description:
@Wrauld wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:32, topic:268386”][quote author=Wrauld link=topic=354206.msg2721929#msg2721929 date=1238031808]

You said it yourself, scripts. Bash scripts are what most people use for their ‘server protection’ needs. If that is not what you mean, post some clarification.
[/quote]i am pretty sure he meant what language would be the best to make a ‘protected server’

A server that can’t get ‘DDOS’ too easily. or BotNetted to easily…
scripts like that, like you have to do mopar, protect your web server.

‘scripts to protect my webserver’ ? What exactly are you trying to do or trying to write? I said the few scripts that I use are Bash scripts. Nothing is actively running on my server to ‘protect’ it though, it runs simply apache on top of linux, which is secure.[/quote]
ic what you mean, I thought people could just ddos your site super easy unless you had a well coded ‘protection’ script.

Read full topic

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @sheepy sheepy
item.description:
@sheepy wrote:

C is shit for security. The language is prone to memory leaks, and security headaches!

Edit: No language is better than another language. I say learn a few so you have a good set of tools to solve your issues.

Read full topic

item.title: Best language to code
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Nowadays my favourite languages are C++, C#, Python and Lua

(Disclaimer: This is a personal opinion and I do not make any warranty, expressed or implied, for the accuracy, completeness, or usefulness of this information)

  • C++ (Not to confuse with C): Very powerful languge, high execution and memory efficiency, but low compilation speed and steep learning curve.

  • C#: Modern language, probably best IDE ever, RAD, good GUIs in a short dev time. Similar to Java, with a different philosophy and a more powerful core language. Not so good for web applets.

  • Python: Dynamic scripting / programming language, fast theorethical dev times but very bad IDEs. Not bad for embedding.

  • Lua: Not good as a stand-alone language, but very good for embedding.

Read full topic
